Topic.Title: Samsung KICKS OUT Qualcoomm for own modem/chipset in a variant of Galaxy S3 LTE smartphone

Message.Msg: A couple of points, if I may. First, how is Samsung moving to the self-design and self-manufacture of their own mobile processors with integrated modems remotely good for nvidia? Hummm? Answer : It is not. Because nvidia now has one less gigantic company to sell their parts to. nvidia's so-called "Total Addressable Market" -- buyers, don't u know -- has shrunk. Icera also loses a gigantic potential customer too. Secondly -- and quite ironically -- Qualcomm will make an Even Higher Profit Margin by Samsung making their own integrated LTE modam chips. "But but but, how can that be, Bestie?" Well, the reason is simple. Because Qualcomm generates licensing revenue, directly or indirectly, on virtually every wireless device manufaturerd on the planet. Yes, each and every one, boys. Witness the summary of Qualcomm's Licensing Unit ("QTL") for the Twelve Months ending September 30, 2012. $6,327,000,000 __ Qualcomm Licensing Revenue $__742,000,000 __ Cost of licensing $5,585,000,000 __ Earnings Before Taxes -- Qualcomm's Licensing Unit 88% __ Earnings Before Taxes as a % of Licensing Revenues A nice gig, right boys? A REALLY REALLY nice gig Qualcomm has going. Collecting licensing fees from virtually every wireless thing that is made on the planet. So Samsung will be payin' patent vig to Qualcomm too. Just like everybody else. And Qualcomm has virtually no-cost of those no-goods-sold. So Qualcomm will have even Higher profit margins on Samsung's self-manufactured mobile processors. Than if Qualcomm actually went through the time and trouble to make 'em. Like nvidia currently tries to do. Did I mention? It's a nice gig for Qualcomm, right boys?

Topic.Title: Samsung KICKS OUT Qualcoomm for own modem/chipset in a variant of Galaxy S3 LTE smartphone

Message.Msg: So Master? If nvidia ever gets their Grey chips working, -- with that on-board LTE integrated modem -- nvidia will have to pay licensing fees to Qualcomm too, right? Just like everybody else. So nvidia's Grey chips will become a new profit center for Qualcomm. Even if it never becomes a profit center for nvidia.

Topic.Title: Samsung KICKS OUT Qualcoomm for own modem/chipset in a variant of Galaxy S3 LTE smartphone

Message.Msg: Qualcomm does not collect licencing fees for LTE, even though it holds a bunch of patents. LTE is a 3GPP standard.

Topic.Title: So Best? If Jen chopped guidance by (-15%), shouldn't the stock fall by (-15%) too?

Message.Msg: Chopping guidance. It's one of those mysterious phenomena that lacks a good explanation. But we all know that it works. It's like Gravity, right? We're not quite sure how gravity works either, but it does. Every time. Or like why domestic turkeys can't fly. Nope, they can't fly, boys. It another mysterious phenomena that lacks a good explanation, right? A "bird" that can't fly. So the CEO announces that the future won't be as good as the past. Sometimes giving a generalized reason like, "Global sales of PC's stink." Which, for a company like nvidia that gets 2/3rds of their revenue from the sale of parts which attach to PC's, is Not a good thing. "Chopping guidance" it's called in the lingo of investing. And what happens After the CEO chops his guidance? Hummm? Down the stock goes. Plumentingly. Just like gravity. Or a domestic turkey attempting to fly. Did I mention? It's one of those mysterious phenomena that lacks a good explanation. But we all know that it works. Every time.

Topic.Title: Tegra/CPB Loses more than Twice (2x) what it Lost last year!

Message.Msg: For the Nine Months ending October 28, 2012 the Tegra/CPB Division wiped-out 32.5% of nvidia's Operating Income, as follows: $434,818,000 __ Operating Income, GPU Business $283,520,000 __ Operating Income, Professional Solutions Business __________ $718,338,000 __ Operating Income without the Tegra/CPB Business ($233,545,000) __ Operating Loss, Tegra/Consumer Products Business ($233,545,000) / $718,338,000 = (32.51%) So Bast? Wouldn't nvidia make a Lot more money for their hapless shareholders WITHOUT the Tegra / Consuming Profits Business? I thought so.

Topic.Title: Is Intel acquisition of Nvidia possible?

Message.Msg: I am not long yet (not to confuse with short term trading) - will wait for some strength back to about 12.75 before the trend reversal is confirmed. Few key events have happened in last few days - TXN/OMAP exit. INTC/CEO retirement. NVDA is a spec stock anyway. Its running on 3 themes: 1. Defend high end GPU, GPGPU market share. AMD and INTC are the main competition. One is in disarray and the other has not been able to deliver (proof Apple going with NVDA for high-end) 2. Further in-roads in Mobile. All the bets are on Wayne and Grey. Amazon will need to move to a new chipset next year. Adreno 320 will be trumped and lampooned by Wayne/GPU at CES. TegraZone games are gaining steam and that will make tablet/video gaming a key differentiator. 3. Project Denver. This has the potential to shake things in cloud market and even on Chromebook style PCs. Again, lot of potential and lot of hurdles - so interesting stock to have on watch list.

Topic.Title: Is Intel acquisition of Nvidia possible?

Message.Msg: "3. Project Denver. This has the potential to shake things in cloud market and even on Chromebook style PCs." It will be one of the many ARMy of ARM64 devices that will be place the x86 under attack... From lessons learned with their GPU, and from INtel... NVidia will own the high-ground. And take positions in the mid-range, and low-end.. long-term the successful squeeze out those in the middle... Look at AMD... they've been squeezed on the x86 by INtel, and their GPUs by NVidia... btw, add Win9 style PCs to your list... It may be tough to see today...but NVIdia's SOCs will be 100% NVidia IP in 2014... CPUs, GPUs, LTE, etc... IMO, NVIdia's entire future hangs on Project Denver... from high-end to low-end... On INTC, you already seeing INtel slowly, relunctantly, painfully...opening up their fabs...

Topic.Title: Is Intel acquisition of Nvidia possible?

Message.Msg: Intel is still working on its own mobile strategy. They've been investing heavily in it and the results should start showing up next year. If that fails miserably then Its slightly more likely they would be interested. However Intel would likely buy a no name company and use them as a starting point. So I have to say no not going to happen.

Topic.Title: Is Intel acquisition of Nvidia possible?

Message.Msg: "Is an Intel acquisition of Nvidia possible?" Forgetta 'bout it, boys. Intel Corporation already bought the right to use each and every existing nvidia patent. And any new patents issued through what, the year 2017? So Intel already Has the right to use ALL of nvidia's intellectual property. Which has already worked out pretty well for Intel with their brand-new, Tesla crushing, highly energy efficient Intel Xeon Phi accelerator cards. So why on earth would Intel want all of that strange-looking used office equipment? Answer : They wouldn't. Just another take-over rumor fabricated by the nvidia pumpers. So Sell the Rumor, boys. And buy the non-news.

Message.Title: Huge trade sees end to Nvidia's slide
Message.Msg: Shares of Nvidia are near two-year lows, but an enormous trade is betting on an end to the bleeding. More than 43,000 NVDA options trade, compared to the daily average of 7,500 in the last month. Puts outpace calls by 10 to 1 in today's session, with almost all of the action in the January 11 puts. More than 37,000 of those contracts have traded against open interest of 3,513. Blocks of 18,000 and 17,500 were sold in a matter of seconds for the bid price of $0.36, according to optionMONSTER's tracking systems. NVDA is up 2.35 percent to $11.76 in afternoon trading. Shares of he graphics-chip maker have been trending lower from above $15 in early August and were down at a low of $11.15 a week ago. The put selling is a wager that NVDA will remain above $11 through the expiration. The trader is also willing to buy shares if they are below the strike, at an effective buying price of $10.64 including the credit from the put sale.

Topic.Title: Is Intel acquisition of Nvidia possible?

Message.Msg: Time is tight and Intel doesn't have much more time as they lose more market share to ARM. They're backs are against the wall, and many scenarios are probably being considered to stop the hemorrhaging? Perhaps they might just bite the bullet and consider buying Nvidia if their band of lawyers say they would have a good chance of passing SEC anti-trust issues? How many years have they been trying with Atom without any success? Intel will always be behind with the bloated legacy x86 issues that will not be able to break the long-time advantage ARM has in pricing, and power savings. Offering Jen the top spot that's now available, along with a generous buy-out price might be something Jen would consider? Jen did make a point of wanting to be in charge of AMD when they wanted to buy Nvidia. Most likely won't happen, but strange things have happened in the past with mergers and acquisitions.

It will be payable on Dec. 14, 2012 to all shareholders of record on Nov. 23, 2012.

Message.Title: NVDA ex-dividend was 11/20
Message.Msg: I know NVDA confused a lot of people by stating shareholders of record 11/23 will be paid a dividend. They should have instead stated ex-dividend date. The reason for discrepancy is that stock transactions take 3 days for settlement and 11/22 is a holiday.

Topic.Title: Huge trade sees end to Nvidia's slide

I went to the broker, compared the closing price Monday night to Tuesday morning. There's no misinterpretation here. The ex-dividend was on the 20th, period. Nvidia may have intended to say the week of the 23rd, not sure. But it's done. Believe me, I thought it could be on the 23rd too, but think about it, why on a half day of trading? I had this confirmed by the brokerage. IT'S ON THE RECORD. Don't be so stubborn and be in denial.

Topic.Title: Huge trade sees end to Nvidia's slide

Message.Msg: "compared the closing price Monday night to Tuesday morning." I've seen Nov 20 on many sites, but Nov23 is the date posted on the NVidia website....

Topic.Title: NVDA ex-dividend was 11/20

Message.Msg: Just got this from the internet: The ex-dividend date is there to help you out as a reminder that you need to purchase your stock several days before the record date in order for you to actually be included as a shareholder on the record date. This is because any single stock purchase or transaction can take up to three stock business days in order to “settle” in your account. It’s the record date that really matters, --------------------------------------------------------------------- So it appears that I am wrong about anyone buying today, or at least the informed buying today...

Topic.Title: Huge trade sees end to Nvidia's slide

Message.Msg: nope it was 11/20, you need to take into account 3 business days for stock settlement and 11/22 being a holiday.
